abstractText: The development of novel zeolite-like materials with large channel windows and high stability is of importance but remains a tremendous challenge. Herein, we report the first example of a 3D covalent organic framework with zeolitic network, namely the zeolitic organic framework (ZOF). By combining two kinds of tetrahedral building blocks with fixed or relatively free bond angles, ZOF-1 with the zeolitic crb net has been successfully synthesized. Its structure was determined by the single-crystal 3D electron diffraction technique. Remarkably, ZOF-1 shows high chemical stability, large pore size (up to 16 Å), and excellent specific surface area (~ 2785 m/g), which is superior to its analogues with the same network, including traditional aluminosilicate zeolites and zeolitic imidazole frameworks. This study thus opens a new avenue to construct zeolite-like materials with pure organic frameworks and will promote their potential applications in adsorption and catalysis for macromolecules. Aluminosilicate zeolite is a class of crystalline microporous inorganic materials that has been employed in a wide variety of practical applications across chemical industries.[1,2] However, the windows and pores of these materials are usually tiny because their frameworks are built from corner-sharing, tetrahedrally coordinated TO4 principal units (where T is a tetrahedral atom, such as Si and Al), which extremely limits their uses in adsorption and catalysis for macromolecules. Subsequently, an inorganic-organic hybrid zeolite-like material, termed zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF), was widely reported, in which transition metals (Zn or Co) substitute tetrahedrally coordinated atoms (for example, Si), and imidazolate linkers replace bridged oxygen atoms.[3,4] Although the pores of ZIFs have been greatly improved, their channel windows are still small, and especially chemical stability of ZIFs is a major issue due to the nature of coordination bonds. Therefore, developing new crystalline zeolite-like materials with large channels and high stability is of importance but remains a great challenge.

references.title: Zeolitic Organic Framework Herein, we report the first case of zeolite-like crystalline porous organic materials, ZOF-1 with high chemical stability, large pore size (up to 16 Å), and excellent specific surface area (~ 2785 m 2 /g), which is superior to its analogues with the same network, including traditional aluminosilicate zeolites and zeolitic imidazole frameworks

Scheme 1. Energy scans analysis of tetrahedral building units as a function of bond angel. (a) Structures of SBF (left) with fixed bond angles as well as TPM (middle) and TPBM (right) with relatively free bond angles. (b) Potential energy scans of different tetrahedral building units based on variable bond angles.
channel windows and high stability is of importance but remains a tremendous challenge. Herein, we report the first example of a 3D covalent organic framework with zeolitic network, namely the zeolitic organic framework (ZOF). By combining two kinds of tetrahedral building blocks with fixed or relatively free bond angles, ZOF-1 with the zeolitic crb net has been successfully synthesized. Its structure was determined by the single-crystal 3D electron diffraction technique. Remarkably, ZOF-1 shows high chemical stability, large pore size (up to 16 Å), and excellent specific surface area (~ 2785 m2/g), which is superior to its analogues with the same network, including traditional aluminosilicate zeolites and zeolitic imidazole frameworks. This study thus opens a new avenue to construct zeolite-like materials with pure organic frameworks and will promote their potential applications in adsorption and catalysis for macromolecules.
Aluminosilicate zeolite is a class of crystalline microporous inorganic materials that has been employed in a wide variety of practical applications across chemical industries.[1,2] However, the windows and pores of these materials are usually tiny because their frameworks are built from corner-sharing, tetrahedrally coordinated TO4 principal units (where T is a tetrahedral atom, such as Si and Al), which extremely limits their uses in adsorption and catalysis for macromolecules. Subsequently, an inorganic-organic hybrid zeolite-like material, termed zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF), was widely reported, in which transition metals (Zn or Co) substitute tetrahedrally coordinated atoms (for example, Si), and imidazolate linkers replace bridged oxygen atoms.[3,4] Although the pores of ZIFs have been greatly improved, their channel windows are still small, and especially chemical stability of ZIFs is a major issue due to the nature of coordination bonds. Therefore, developing new crystalline zeolite-like materials with large channels and high stability is of importance but remains a great challenge.
[] Y. Liu, Dr. Y. Wang, J. Suo, J. Ding, Dr. L. Zhu, Prof. S. Qiu,
Prof. Q. Fang State Key Laboratory of Inorganic Synthesis and Preparative Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, China E-mail: qrfang@jlu.edu.cn or wyujie@jlu.edu.cn Dr. P. Chen, Prof. J. Sun College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Beijing National Laboratory for Molecular Sciences Peking Univer-sity, Beijing 100871, China E-mail: junliang.sun@pku.edu.cn Prof. V. Valtchev Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences 189 Song Ling Rd, Qingdao, Shandong 266101, China Normandie Univ, ENSICAEN, UNICAEN, CNRS, Laboratoire Catalyse et Spectrochimie, 6 Marechal Juin, 14050 Caen, France Prof. Y. Yan Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Center for Catalytic Science and Technology, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19716, USA
[ † ] These authors contributed equally to this work.
Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [5,6] are an emerging
class of crystalline porous polymers that are assembled from organic building blocks linked by covalent bonds. Since the initiated work of Yaghi in 2005, these materials have attracted extensive attention in different fields, such as energy storage, gas separation, heterogeneous catalysis, optoelectronics, and many others.[7-16] Recently, developing three-dimensional (3D) COF materials has been considered indispensable because of their promising advantages in interconnected pores and higher specific surface areas than two-dimensional (2D) counterparts. [17-19] Up to now, the building units in 3D architectures are
mostly on the basis of the tetrahedral (4-connected, Td) geometry, such as the derivatives of tetraphenylmethane, tetraphenylsilane, and adamantine.[20-23] A few successful examples with higher numbers of connections (> 4 points of extension) have been reported, e.g., a 3D cage-based COF with a twofold interpenetrated acs net[24] and polycubane COFs with the bcu net based on cubic (8-connected) units.[25] By applying triangular prism (6-connected, D3h) triptycene linkers as node centers, we also designed a series of 3D COFs with various networks, such as JUC-564 with stp net,[26] JUC-568 and JUC-569 with ceq or acs net,[27] as well as JUC-596 and JUC-597 with hea net.[28] However, it is still a challenge to obtain building units with a high extension due to the difficulties in the synthesis and purification. It should be noted that aluminosilicate zeolites as a widely-used crystalline porous material could be constructed to obtain more than 250 topologies by simple tetrahedral geometry (SiO4 or AlO4).[29] In principle, more novel frameworks in 3D COFs, such as zeolite-like networks, could be also created by tetrahedral moieties as interlinked centers rather than just a limited number of topologies, e.g., dia, ctn, bor, and pts.[30-37] However, this avenue has not yet been explored.
Scheme 2. A strategy for constructing ZOF-1 with crb net. Molecular structures of TMSFTA (a) as a tetrahedral building unit with fixed bond angles and BMTA (b) as a tetrahedral building unit with relatively free bond angles. (c) A novel 3D COF with zeolitic crb net, ZOF-1, constructed from the condensation reaction of TMSFTA and BMTA. (d) Non-interpenetrated crb net and (e) twofold interpenetrated crb net.
3
Herein, we report a 3D COF with the zeolitic net, namely zeolitic organic framework (ZOF). By employing two kinds of tetrahedral building units with fixed or relatively free bond angles, we successfully design and synthesize a crystalline porous ZOF with zeolitic crb net (namely zeolite BCT),[38] termed ZOF-1, which has been determined its structure by the single-crystal 3D electron diffraction (ED) technique. Notably, ZOF-1 displays excellent chemical stability, large pore size (~ 16 Å), and specific surface area (~ 2785 m2/g), which is much higher than its analogues with the same net, such as traditional aluminosilicate zeolites and zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs). To the best of our knowledge, this study represents the first case of zeolite-like crystalline porous organic materials.
In order to construct a novel COF with the zeolitic net, our strategy is based on the reasonable regulation of tetrahedral building units by reticular chemistry.[39] As shown in Scheme 1, we performed potential energy scans of three tetrahedral building units, 9,9′-spirobifluorene (SBF), tetraphenylmethane (TPM) and 3,3′,5,5′-tetraphenyl-bimesitylene (TPBM), as the bond angles changed between ± 10º by using Gaussian 09 software package.[40] Obviously, the relatively free TPM and TPBM showed small energy changes (~ 8 kJ/mol), demonstrating that such building blocks are apt to form a traditional structure with dia net, an optimal conformation based on the lowest energy, by altering their bond angles.[19] Different with flexible TPM and TPBM, SBF as a highly fixed linker exhibited major changes of the energy (~ 60 kJ/mol),
which indicates that it will probably tend to set up new architectures instead of the traditional optimal dia network
due to the hard-to-change bond angles. Based on this strategy, we synthesized a derivative of SBF containing aldehyde groups, 2,2′,7,7′-tetramethoxy-9,9′-spirobifluorene-3,3′,6,6′tetracarbaldehyde (TMSFTA, Scheme 2a). By the condensation of TMSFTA and a building unit containing amino groups, 3,3′,5,5′-tetra(p-aminophenyl)-bimesitylene (BMTA, Scheme 2b), we successfully developed the first 3D COF with the zeolitic net, ZOF-1 (Scheme 2c).
Typically, the synthesis of ZOF-1 was carried out by suspending TMSFTA and BMTA in a mixed solution of n-butyl alcohol and 1,2-dichlorobenzene with the presence of 9 M acetic acid aqueous solution, followed by heating at 120 ºC for 3 days. Complementary methods were employed for precise structural determination and characterization. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and image revealed that ZOF-1 exhibited approximate rectangular crystals (Figure S1). The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra demonstrated the formation of ZOF-1 by a newly appeared C=N stretching peak at 1615 cm-1 and the disappearance of N-H stretching band at 3310~3400
Figure 3. (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of ZOF-1 at 77 K. (b) H2 adsorption of ZOF-1 at 77 K and 87 K. (c) Uptakes of CO2, CH4 and N2 of ZOF-1 at 273 K. Inset: pore-size distribution of ZOF-1.
cm-1 and C=O stretching band at 1696 cm-1, manifesting the completed conversion of Schiff-base polymerization (Figure S2). Solid-state 13C cross-polarization magic-angle-spinning (CP/MAS) NMR spectroscopy of ZOF-1 further verified the presence of a new C=N bond by the peak at 162 ppm (Figure S3). In addition, ZOF-1 showed high thermal stability (up to 300 °C) according to the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under nitrogen gas, and excellent chemical stability for the stable existence in different organic solvents and aqueous solutions for 24 h, such as strong acid (HCl with pH = 1) and strong base (NaOH with pH = 14, Figures S4-9).
The unit cell and crystal structure of ZOF-1 were resolved by a 3D ED technique continuous rotation electron diffraction (cRED, Figures 1b and S10). The cRED data were collected on a JEOL 2100-plus TEM equipped with MerlinEM direct electron detector under 200 kV acceleration voltage at 100 K. The data were visualized with program RED[41] and processed using XDS[42] with the aid of Instamatic[43] for batch processing. These data were recorded with the tilting angle from -51.12° to 63.86°. Each frame was collected with an exposure time of 1 s, resulting in a 0.75° wedge per frame. The resolution cutoff was set to 2.0 Å according to the criteria of I/σ > 1. The diffraction can be indexed with the cell parameter of a = 30.37 Å, b = 30.00 Å, c = 18.71 Å, α = 89.79°, β = 89.78°, and γ = 90.09°. Pointless[44] analysis indicated that the diffraction belongs to Cmmm Laue group and not to a tetragonal lattice. Thus, the unit cell was converted to an orthorhombic C-lattice with the cell parameters of a = 42.62 Å, b = 42.76 Å, c = 18.73 Å. Due to the low resolution (2.0 Å), we turned to the molecular replacement method (Phaser).[45] The initio positions of two monomers were found using this method, and they were then adjusted manually to form a continuous network. Finally, the model was optimized by Forcite module in the Materials Studio with COMPASS II force field (Table S1).[46] In light of these results, ZOF-1 was defined as a 3D framework with twofold interpenetrated crb net and interconnected channels (up to 16 Å, Scheme 2d, 2e, and Figures 2, S14, S15).
The structure of ZOF-1 was also studied via PXRD combined with the structural simulation. The experimental PXRD pattern of ZOF-1 was in good agreement with the calculated one from the cRED model (Figure S11). Full profile pattern matching (Pawley) refinement was carried out. As shown in Figure 1a, peaks at 2.92°, 4.13°, 5.55°, 6.29°, and 7.54° could be attributed to the (110), (200), (111), (201), and (131) Bragg peaks. The refinement results yielded similar unit cell parameters with good agreement factors (Rp = 5.91% and ωRp = 6.78%). An alternative structure, a non-interpenetrated crb net, was also set up; however, its simulated PXRD did not match the experimental one (Figure S12).
The permanent porosity and specific surface area of ZOF-1 were obtained by N2 adsorption analysis at 77 K. As shown in Figure 3a, a sharp increase was observed at low pressure (below 0.1 P/P0), which reveals a microporous nature. The slight desorption hysteresis and inclination above 0.9 P/P0 can be attributed to textural mesopores from the agglomeration of crystals.[47] According to its N2 adsorption isotherm, the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) specific surface area of ZOF-1 was as high as 2785 m2/g (Figure S13). Furthermore, the poresize distribution was calculated by nonlocal density functional
theory (NLDFT), which is in good agreement with those of the crystal structure (Figure 3a, inset). Remarkably, ZOF-1 displayed an impressive BET surface area (2785 m2/g) and pore size (up to 16 Å) compared to other zeolite-like materials with the same crb net, including traditional aluminosilicate zeolites and ZIFs, such as BTC zeolite (3 Å),[48] ZIF-1 (3 Å),[49] ZIF-2 (6 Å),[49] and ZIF-64 (6 Å),[50] which demonstrates that such pure organic frameworks have fascinating potential due to their high surface areas and large pores (Table S2).
We further investigated the H2 adsorption performance of ZOF-1. As shown in Figures 3b, ZOF-1 showed a high capacity in H2 uptake up to 223 cm3/g (1.99 wt%) at 77 K and 154 cm3/g (1.38 wt%) at 87 K at 1 bar, which is comparable with best performing porous materials, such as CTC-COF (125 cm3/g or 1.12 wt%),[51] MOF-177 (139 cm3/g or 1.25 wt%),[52] PAF-1 (179 cm3/g or 1.60 wt%).[53] Furthermore, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) of ZOF-1 for H2 was calculated to be 6.37 kJ/mol (Figure S16). In addition, we studied the potential application of ZOF-1 for CO2 adsorption and separation. The adsorption isotherms of CO2, N2, and CH4 were measured at 273 K (Figure 3c). Notably, the sorption amount of ZOF-1 for CO2 was as high as 78.78 cm3/g, which is much higher than the other two gases, CH4 (32.34 cm3/g) and N2 (7.01 cm3/g). The ideal adsorption selectivity of ZOF-1 was calculated from the ratio of the initial slopes based on the Henry region of the isotherms (Figure S17), and good selectivity of CO2/N2 (6.7) or CO2/CH4 (19.1) was observed (Table S3).
In summary, we successfully designed and synthesized a zeolite-like crystalline porous organic material, ZOF-1 with the zeolitic crb net, by using two kinds of tetrahedral building blocks with fixed or relatively free bond angles, TMSFTA and BMTA. The crystal structure of ZOF-1 was well determined by a cRED technique as well as PXRD patterns combined with the structural simulation. Furthermore, ZOF-1 showed high chemical stability, large pore size (~ 16 Å), and exceptional specific surface area (~ 2785 m2/g), which exceeds its analogues with the same framework involving traditional aluminosilicate zeolites and ZIFs. Therefore, this work expands a new avenue to create crystalline zeolite-like materials constructed from organic building units and will facilitate their promising potentials for adsorption and catalysis of large molecules.

Zeolitic Organic Framework
Herein, we report the first case of zeolite-like crystalline porous organic materials, ZOF-1 with high chemical stability, large pore size (up to 16 Å), and excellent specific surface area (~ 2785 m 2 /g), which is superior to its analogues with the same network, including traditional aluminosilicate zeolites and zeolitic imidazole frameworks. Yaozu Liu, † Pohua Chen, † Yujie Wang, Jinquan Suo, Jiehua Ding, Liangkui Zhu, Valentin Valtchev, Yushan Yan, Shilun Qiu, Junliang Sun, and Qianrong Fang __________ Page – Page
